text: Bottle at Maxs. clear dark Amber with small white head. Aroma is tart strawberry, medium body, lower carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is malt, strawberries, oak, some molasses, and a little bourbon. Nice beer, pretty easy to drink.
On tap at Beercraft. Pours a brown color without much head. Strawberry fruit wafts from the glass. Tingling sourness. The strawberry clashes a little with the base beer.

4/22/17. 375mL bottle from Growler Spot, picked out by Mrs. Owl. Amber pour with a nice khaki head, good lacing. Nice aroma, sour, mild barrel, plenty of strawberry. Awesome flavor, sour as all get out, strawberries, light barrel. Delish!

Got in a BIF from Roguer. 375 ml bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 7/14/2016. Pours slightly hazy pinkish golden/orange color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense and fluffy off white head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of big juicy strawberries, lightly tart lemon, green apple, raspberry, cherry, red grape, brown sugar, and toasted oak; with light hay, leather, musty funk, bourbon, pepper, and yeast/oak earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of strawberries, malt/sugars, oak barrel, and light-moderate fruity/funky yeast notes; with great strength. Taste of huge tart/sour raspberry, strawberry, lemon, green apple, red grape, brown sugar, and toasted oak; with light hay, leather, musty funk, bourbon, vanilla, pepper, red wine vinegar, and yeast/oak earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/lactic sourness and light yeast/oak spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of sour raspberry, strawberry, lemon, green apple, red grape, brown sugar, toasted oak, red wine vinegar, light musty funk, and yeast/oak earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/funky/acidic yeast, strawberries, malt/sugars, and oak barrel flavors; with a great malt/sourness balance. Lightly puckering, but not astringent after the finish. Moderate dryness from acidity/oak tannins, increasing through the glass. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth and moderately acidic/tannic/grainy balanced mouthfeel that is nice. Mildly warming alcohol for 9.7%. Overall this is an outstanding fruited sour ale! All around awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/funky/acidic yeast, strawberries, malt/sugars, and oak barrel flavors; very smooth and easy to sip on for the big ABV; and despite the increasingly lactic/tannic/drying finish. Interesting contrast between aromas and flavors. Nose was very sweet and juicy on fruit notes, with much less funk/sourness; but the taste was much more in line with what I expected for a sour ale on flavor complexity. A highly enjoyable offering.

Draft @ Sour Sunday 2017, Berkeley, CA. Pours a hazy orange pale amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity sour tart berry aroma. Fruity sour tart woody strawberry flavor. Has a fruity sour tart woody berry finish.

Poured from a 375 ml bottle dated July 14, 2016. 
Aroma is nice and fairly strawberry forward. Some cherry, and other berry notes with a bit of fig and raisin. Light oak notes with some hints of bourbon and alcohol spice. Some light caramel and toffee notes. 
Pours a slightly murky, reddish brown with a small, somewhat thin, tan head that quickly recedes and disappears. No lacing and moderate length legs. 
Flavor is fairly sweet with some moderate acidity in the finish. Medium light strawberry notes with tart cherries, berries, raisin and figs. Light caramel and toffee notes with a bit of biscuit and cracker malt notes as well. Some light oak with hints of bourbon and some light alcohol spice in the finish. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium to medium high carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, one of the best strawberry beers I have had. It does not have even a hint of the weird phenolic note that so many strawberry beers get and the strawberry character is fairly well pronounced, especially in the aroma. Nice fruity notes in the acidity and the bourbon and oak notes are light and add some nice complexity in the background.

Bottled July 14, 2016. Listed as 9.7%. Pours hazy to murky copper with nearly flat off-white head. Aroma of strawberries, oak barrels, red wine, huge aroma...! Taste is rich berry tart with light funky side notes, rich oak barrels, mild berry sweet finish. Light and crisp body with average to lively carbonation.
Bottle. Pours cloudy gold, with a small, white head. Aroma is strawberries, wood, lemons,and some funk. Flavor is sour, with strawberries, wood. lemons, funk, and a small amount of bourbon.

A bit messy and all over the place but i cant help that i like it a lot. Aroma is super fresh strawberries, oak, some nutty notes, bourbon, and bread. Taste is tons of fresh bourbony strawberries. Reminds me of a new non existent dessert, strawberries foster.
A tad tart. Lots of fruit flavor. A sweetness on the finish that is pretty unique. Big bodied. Big flavored. Lots going on here.

Bottle from Londonderry Quick Stop
Hazy murky amber brown with a thin wisp of a white head that dissipates instantly. Great berry on the nose but the tart lurking underneath makes you stand at attention. Tart earthy berry flavor with a hint of alcohol and what could be some hop bitterness? Medium body tart lemony puckering mouthfeel, moderate carbonation. Pretty tasty beer, the strawberry is well done!
Pours deep mahogany into a tulip. Strawberry and funk aromas. Dry with sweet strawberry and tart cherry and oak front to back. Parching acidic finish.

Im sorry.... I enjoy beer but do not get caught up in all the nomenclature. Trust me, I despise Bud Light and anything main stream. I enjoy many types of robust beers and enjoy about any type of beer that is unique albeit I lack the acceptable terms for what it smells/tastes like. Again, Im sorry for my lack of the proper terms among true beer connoisseurs ... but this was absolutely TERRIBLE! What a terrible, fruity, sour mess. This must only be considered "beer" by the definition of the brewing process vs other alcoholic beverages only. It is absolutely foul and undrinkable. I would rather mop the bathroom and drink the left over water. I read the reviews on here and immediately lost all faith in humanity and fellow beer lovers. I signed up ONLY to warn others that dont smell their beer like a wine snob every time they pop a top to STEER CLEAR. For shame Allagash.... and to think my middle name is named after this beautiful, rouged area of our great State of Maine.

Bottle via Stateline... Great nose of fresh strawberries. Average looking red murky color with small head. Taste is a solid Belgian ale. Malt body, bread notes, balanced bitterness....Little sweet with a tartness, followed by a strawberry aftertaste. But not like a sweet girly drink. Body is light and bubbly. I was surprised to see the alcohol content, hidden really well. Easy to drink for a high ABV. Overall, I can dig it but doubt I would get again just do to the price tag.

Shared 12.7 oz. bottle poured to a snifter, showing a cloudy, light amber color, with modest, bubbly, off white foam, and light spots of lacing. The nose was a bit of barnyard funk, pronounced strawberry, tartness, just a touch of dark caramel & treacle sweetness, with some barrel/tannic scent. Medium bodied, the taste was similar notes, possessing more of a sour nature that somewhat masked the level of effervescence, which was low, imo, with some pleasant warmth, and finishing dryness. Nicely matured Four.

Looks like grape plum juice. no head. smells like grape jelly with baked plum. interesting. oooh holy sour. tart with some ham smoked salty taste. cherry pie in the middle. sweet and juicy flavor with a slight bit of oak

375ml. Bottled 7/14/16. Aroma is sour berries. Taste is strawberry. Lots of sourness, very acidic, low sweetness. 

Finish has slight oak and bourbon.

Draft at armsby abbey. Pours golden with a thin white head. Nice fruity and tart notes on the nose and tongue. Puckers the mouth with tartness which is nice. Finished clean. Nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft. Crystal clear copper body topped by small off-white head. Aroma is moderately sweet, molasses, some caramel, strawberry, light Bourbon. Taste is sweet, caramel/molasses, light berry, Bourbon, alcohol warming. Sticky medium-full body, low carbonation.

Copenhagen Beer and Music Celebration Boston: pours bright red with a big white head. Aroma is strawberries, wood and wine. Taste is quite sour. Loads of wood and berries. Deep and complex. Alcohol well covered. Tasty as always.

Ok...maybe as a female child of the late 80s this has ruined me, but the combo of oak and strawberry smells and tastes like my plastic play kitchen bakery set. I cant get into this. Maybe its good. But I taste and smell plastic, like sour bandaids. Haunting me. Lovely memories, but I dont want it in my beer. Hazy brown red. Mouth is sour tart. Tap

Keg at Citizen Burger Charlottesville, 4/20/16. Hazy red-bronze, thin creamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of tart berries, funk, oak, whiskey, vanilla. The taste is oak, lacto, funk, bright and tart strawberry, vanilla and plum. Medium bodied, lingering tartness, a bit phenolic. Nice.

Nose is pleasant. Super sour. I f I had to guess I'd probably say strawberry is the fruit it was aged on. Pretty cool that the strawberries come through on the taste and would have someone actually guess it. Very, very acidic. Bites the hell out of the tongue. Very good beer. If you like sours!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Arlington. Poured a hazy pink with hardly any head. Aroma and flavor are loaded with acetone. Begind that is a solid jammy strawberry, toast, lemon sourness. Nice body, medium to fuller with strong carbonation and a lingering acidic burn. Solid.

Bottle. Pours hazy deep orange, large off white head, dissipates slowly, decent lacing. Aroma starts a bit of nail polish, dust, must, strawberry. Flavor is better, but still a bit of acetone, plenty of strawberry, light plus tart, medium funk. Medium body.
Strawberries and sour plum. Hazy brown pour with ok head and lacing. Tangy finish. Some light citrus. Should be a sour not Belgian strong.

Hazy brown color with a small, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel malts, wood, nuts, strawberries, brett, bacteria. Taste of caramel, spices, wood, strawberries, and a tart finish.

This gets classified as a Belgian strong ale, but really should be a sour. The base is a quad, but it is then aged and soured.   Aroma is quite nice, slight sweet strawberry with some lactic sour. Taste is a lactic sour, maybe 4 of 10 sour, strawberry slight sweetness with a bit of a band aide funk finish. It is all lactic until the finish and then a weird band aide funk. Not malty, which I would expect if it is the Four. Full flavored and complex, but body doesnt seem like a quad. Really quite nice overall. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Very complex aroma, with sour and tart notes mixing with molasses and a good amount of strawberry. Quite sour, pushing slightly into acetic territory, but still very good. Strawberry aroma and molasses mouthfeel. One complex beer!

Poured from a tap. A coppery orange color, small white head. Mild sour fruit and yeast aroma. Medium body with a nice tart yeast flavor and a medium finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This poured a murky purplish brown with a beige head. Aroma was of brown sugar, dark fruits, lots of vanilla oaky character, chocolate, pretty complex. Flavor just as complex, deep caramel malts, brown sugar, strawberry and raspberries, vanilla oak and chocolate, awesome.
Dark purple brown pour, slight white foam, light strawberry aroma, dark fruit. Taste is quite dry and not that sour.

375 ml bottle poured into a brandy snifter. Pours a darker brown with a red tint. The aroma has nice strawberry character, but also hits hard with sourness. The tadte is sweet strawberry and lasting sourness. Really tasty beer. Medium to high carbonation with a big body. When the cork came loose on this beer, it bounced off the ceiling!
Bottle. Nice vino, barrel, apricot, bread and sugar notes. Well blended. I liked it a lot.

Bottle. Belgian Strong? nope. Sour? yes. A strong berry aroma, with a bit of grape character. pour is a hazy reddish color. large white head with tiny bubbles. Taste is a lightly puckering, slightly peppery berry mix up. Definitely tart, but the fruit character comes through without any off flavors (had a lot of bad strawberry beer lately). Some tannins and wood character with a light astringency come through after a few sips. damn good.

On tap @ SLL. Pours a hazy brownish amber color with a one finger beige head that fell slowly to a ring. Strong aromas of bourbon in the nose along with some notes of strawberries and sourness. The taste is very similar to the aroma but the flavors are a bit stronger. The bourbon really stands out in the overall taste but isnt overpowering; there are notes of light strawberry and a mild sourness along with a solid malt base, hints of oak and brown sugar through the finish. Lighter body, moderate carbonation, and a semi dry finish.

375 ml bottle from lukaduke shared with the group. Pours a hazy amber color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have tart/sour strawberries, oak, some acidity, hints of the abv show through, very tasty, curious why this wasnt a sour as it has noticeable tart/sour character.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2014 Bottle shared alexsdad06. Poured hazy copper color with an average off-white frothy head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Medium to heavy complex fruit, wood and alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy complex sweet & sour flavor with medium to heavy fruity sweet & sour finish and a small bite of alcohol. Standout brew.

375 ml bottle to snifter (shared by alexsdad06). Looks good; a very hazy dark apricot with off-white head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells good too; tart and mildly oaky with notes of strawberry and some mild, well-balanced sweetness in the background. Tastes like it smells with a nice mouth-puckering mouthfeel thats on the medium-full side body-wise. Good stuff!

Orange amber color, and very very light carbonation and that was perfect for this particular brew, fruity candy aroma very pleasant. Flavor of malts and very slight candi sugar and great slight strawberry fruitness and cherry skins. Great finish!
Bottle from Schiller. Pours cloudy amber with a thin off white head. The nose is sour strawberries, funk and vinegar. The taste is berry skins, light funk and ripe strawberries. Medium bodied. 4.0

An experimental twist on the Allagash Four barley wine, matured on oak and macerated with strawberries. Stable, off-white head, misty bronze colour, aroma very much dominated by strawberries - not my favorite scent and therefore not quite to my liking, notes of wood, banana, marzipan, medium dry sherry, sour cream, cognac, passion fruit. Complex taste with an interesting game between sweet and sour, as in an oud bruin, fruity yeast, strawberries coming through but less strongly than I feared, woody and vinous, candi syrup, sourishness wins the game and renders a dry, woody, resinous finish. Interesting and complex, a lot going on here.

375 ml bottle shared by TwoSipDip at RBSG - thanks, Tony! Pours a cloudy rose-tinted color with a small off-white head. Notes of strawberry, dry grains, lemon, minerals, oak, yogurt, and doughy malts. Light-medium bodied, with a fruity mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Very nice.
Bottle shared at RBSG. Thanks NielsenRatings! Pours a hazy golden orange color with white head. Strawberry, white fruit, sweet aromas. Strawberry, champagne, fruity flavors.

Bottle shared at Thursday nights Presidential Suite sharing session during RBSG 2014. Thanks! Cloudy golden brown with off-white head. Aromas of oak, raspberries, tart fruit, vinegar, strawberries. Tastes of strawberries, oak, Brett, vinegar. Medium-light body with a dry finish. Very nice.

On tap w/ Leighton & Blake at Top Hops NYC. Big oakey strawberry & notes of construction site on the nose. Biting sour yet sweet, some funk in the trunk. Light/med mouthfeel, strong tart / playful carbonation.
Bottled. A standout, very nice oakiness and faint strawberry, though there in larger quantities than most, good sourness.
Bottle - Tart strawberry. Cloudy copper. Tart strawberry with a nice long finish.

Bottle tasted at RBSG. Orange amber color. Thin ring of off-white head. dots of lace. Awesome big strawberry aroma. Lightly spicy. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. Lightly slick finish. Nice tart taste, lightly spicy, moderate sweet. Awesome strawberry sour.
Bottle. Pours orange. White head. Nose and taste of strawberry, oak, molasses, peach and sour funky fruit. Medium body.

Bottle @ the peteing zoo. Pours a pinkish ruby appearance with an off white head. Definitely tons of strawberries, oak, slight plastic, yeasty nose. Pretty high carbonation. Some plastic. Thick strawberry flavor. Moderately tart. Slight tannins. Kind of fun but not my favorite. Thanks Luke!

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2014 Drafts at Khyber Pass. Having the Four and Avance simultaneously. Hazy red orange pour with a foamy white ring. Both look the same but taste dramatically different. Whereas the Four is a creamy Quad, the Avance is a very strong sour. Strawberry on the nose. Similar to the Oudbete - both taste like battery acid (meaning that in the best way possible) but fuller and fruitier. Damn good stuff!

Wow, the best strawbs sour I ever had. The aroma brings perfectly blended strawberry sweetness and wild yeast. Flavor brings tart rich strawberry notes on a cutting but perfectly smooth dry tart berry body! Wow Rob, fabulous!
Draft at Strong Place, Brooklyn. Reddish pour, strawberry tartness, very acidic and tart. Strong berry notes, straw and rasp. Acidic and tart, medium mouthfeel. Very nice

Draft at blind tiger with Andy and max. Pours a light clear amber bod with light fizzy lacing. Aroma is tart sour fruit - strawberry and lychee. Mouthfeel is super acetic with notes of sour fruit, acid and light funk. Nice but as warned beforehand, a bit too acetic.
Bottle (Batch 1). Poured a amberish color with an off white head. Berries, woody, vanilla, and lighter vinegar in the tastes. Lighter sour finish.
On tap at The Trappist. Pours reddish copper with an attractive beige head and a candi sugar aroma. There is a sour strawberry-laced caramel malt flavor with lots of oak.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2014 Échantillonné du Extreme beer fest 2014: Une bonne dose de fruits rouges trop mûrs balancées par une brillante acidité et le côté beurré du brett. Leffervescence est vive et fait fondre le liquide dans ma bouche.

Wandered into The Jeffrey forgetting it was Allagash night, sweet! This pours ruby orange with great nose of funk, wood and berry. Tastes of lovely amount of fresh strawberries nit overpowering and syrupy or fake tasting. You also get plent of oak, funk, vanilla, and its plenty jammy. Tart palate lingering finish. Kick ass beer
on draft at EBF, BOOM, laser show. one of the best of the night, sharp acidity well balanced with huge fruit forward flavors. Good sweetness to get you the elite trifecta. Allagash did a great job.

On tap at the Pourhouse. Easily the best in show this day. Aroma is sweet tart candy, strawberry, and lemonade. Pours blush wine colored with slight film and decent carbonation. Taste is epic. Sour lemon, strawberry, stilton cheese, sour patch kid candies, and almost a honey finish. This is such a perfect sour. I love everything about this.

Batch 1.

Heavy strawberry presence. Hints of molasses sweetness. Touch of band-aid, sadly. Very lively carbonation, feels a bit strange in that regard. Tasty but a very strange beer.

375ml bottle pours hazy toasted orange with a finger of head. Nose is tart acidic funk, balanced fruity strawberry, must. Taste is rustic sour bready berry, musty wood, horseblanket, funk, some acidity. Finish is funky sour dough, barrel, with lingering balanced strawberry, a touch of acidity on the tail end. Very nice.

Hazy amber brown in color... Aroma of bourbon oak, fresh strawberry jam... Flavor is strawberries, oak, caramel, bourbon hints... Really enjoyable 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cant remember who I got this from but thanks - brought it to Sammys for a tasting. Bottle. I enjoy the base beer at the right age immensely...this was a milder version of the base beer but with lots of strawberries, quite dry, malty, delicious, easy to drink, oak, moderate body and body, tart and tasty.
Thick strawberry. Very jammy though not overly sweet. Above average mouthfeel.Thanks for sharing, Pushinkow.

Brewvival 2011. Hazy amber body large rocky tan head
Sweet fruit, rum soaked fruit caramel with light tart
Sweet lightly tart fruit cherry and caramel flavor
Medium body mod high carb

This is a powerful and memorable beer. To me it was a combination of sour and leather. Both tastes very prominent. It puckers you up and then smacks you around with that funky leathery/barnyard taste.

Tap at meridian pint august 2013
Pours hazy dee red hue witb no head. Nose is crazy barrel age strawberries tart notes lite funk its insane!!! Flavors are sour tart strawberries wood vanilla oak woody this is insane!!! Big beer here however no heat really detected. Long tart sour finish of lingering wood vanilla and strawberries. This is insane good!!! Wow!
pale colored sour ale, complex estery aromas, with a really nice sweet fruit finish.
oak aged Four with wild yeast, strawberries and molasses for 2 years. served in small 25cl Allagash glass, tart nose, reddish hazy w/ little head. Taste is tart with some depth to it

Sampled at the Raleigh Rare and Vintage Festival 2013.  Clear amber pour.   Great aroma that smells like strawberries, but tastes like those fake candies with the strawberry wrappers that your grandma used to give you whenever youd go visit.  Very carbonated and lightly  tart and acidic.

Soooooo gooood.  Murky red orange pour.  Wooonderful nose,  tart and wild notes with lots of berries and a light creamy sweetness.  Hard to get all this down in a festival setting.  Lightly acidic flavor with a very clean and delicate strawberry character.  Funky finish with a light tannic grip.  Loved it.

Tap at rrbf.  hazy orange with a small fizzy white head.  Nose is earthy and heavy strawberry, some funk, oak, and minerals.   Flavor is similarly heavy on the strawberry, funk, most of the base beer is lost which is okay with me.

Pour on tap at the Denver Rare Beer Tasting 2012, hazy orange pour with thin white head, aroma brought notes of oak, slight strawberry, hints of dark fruits, toffee, caramel, hints of grain, spice, slight red fruit in there as well, hints of tart lemon as well, funky tones come through as well.  Taste is a nice mix of red fruits and white fruits, some strawberry, raspberry, hints of peach, slight dark fruit, caramel and toffee, hints of oak, funk and tart lemony notes, finishing fairly bitter, slightly tart, and funky.  Good.

Bottle 375ml. corked.ABV: 10.8%. Clear medium amber red colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, toasted, moderate yeasty, wood, strawberry, light oak - brett. Flavour is moderate to light heavy sweet and light acidic with a long duration, strawberry, tart, wood, light leather - funky. Body is medium, texture is oily and sticky, carbonation is soft. [20121019]
Served in an Allagash coolship tumbler.  Nose has a good dose of barrel character and noticeable strawberry. Flavor is too oxidized. Dry and slightly sour.

Shared by Thorpe429 alongside several other Allagash sour/wild ales. Thank you very much, Mike!

The beer is light brown with subtle highlights of crimson and pink. The aroma brings a grandiose scent of strawberries soaked in alcohol. Subtle notes of oak. While the beer brings some potent flavor, the swetness of the alcohol and strawberries, a naturally sweet fruit, together is a bit overbearing. Medium bodied with moderately light carbonation. Alcohol presence is bold throughout. Mostly sweet with a touch of tartness. Overall, this was OK.

Birthday bottle from a friend ! Pours a deep rusty red color with a two finger off white foam that settles but caps nicely.  On the nose its interesting slight phenol band aid hints but more sweet burnt sugar, tart strawberry,  and wet barrel funky earth notes. On the palate damn... complex, elegant and tasty. Big burnt cookie notes, cocoa and dark sugar mingle with berry notes and tart hints of soured wet barrels.... nice complex earthy finish.
Bottle @ French Oktoberfest Tasting Ulfborg, 2012. Pours deep ruby amber with a small white head. Fresh ripe strawberries, funk and mild caramel. Woody. Tasty and dry. Nice.

Sample at Denver Rare Beer Tasting IV on 10/12/2012. The beer pours a hazed reddish-brown color with a medium light beige head that recedes steadily. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of berries and oak. Full-bodied with flavors of oak, sweet malt and strawberries. The finish is tart with a berry aftertaste. Good overall.

Tap.  Pours clear tawny with a small, fizzy off-white head, short retention with spare lacing.  Aroma is strawberry, bubble gum and bandaid phenols, cookie and caramel malt with light earthy hops.  Flavor is medium strawberry, dry malt, cookie and caramel malt with light hops and bitterness with a sweet finish.  Full body and medium carbonation.

Tap. Pours cloudy brown with thin, creamy white head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is berries, oak, bread and cookie malt, yeast, spice, and floral hops. Flavor is sour fruit esters and sweet malts with light hops and oak notes; dry, tart finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Had at the 2012 Denver Rare Beer Tasting in Denver, Colorado. Has some very nice sour like funk with lemon/cherry scents, has a nice barrel character in the taste.

rubinrød klar skum lidt hvid kort 
jordbær vinøs malt svovl vanlije 
sur moderat bitter lidt

Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Hazy reddish amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, bretty, wood and strawberries. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate acidic. Dry and moderate acidic finish. 191012

Bottle @ FoneFan, 10.8%. Slight hazy dark amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, strawberries, sour and oak. Flavour is malt, strawberries, sour, oak, wood, little acetone and a little vinegar.
Served at Denver Rare Beer Tasting 2012. Not much notes, but really enjoyed this one. Tart nose sour flavor delicious.

Pour at the Denver Rare Beer Tasting IV. Appearance is hazy orange with a big off-white head. Woody, tannin, sour fruity, peachy, berry aroma. Taste is like tart peach skin, apricots, green apples, wood, and grape skins. Light body with high carbonation. Very sour beer, enamel melting of sorts, yet so well-balanced and the overbearing vinegar tastes that so many American sours have is not present at all in this one. Great Beer!!

Draught at Churchkey. This should probably be a sour ale. Absolutely stunning nose and flavor, with dark fruit notes of cherry, plum, fig, and a gorgeous sour strawberry component. Oak and tannins abound. Absolutely awesome.
Night of the Funk 2012. Mad delicious. Huge dark fruit and stone fruit with oaky tannins and ecellent lactic and earthy tartness. Mmmmm...

On tap at Maine Craft beer review at ChurchKey in DC. Hazy reddish brown with a nice tan head. Nose is woody with a hint of berry. Served at the perfect temperature to taste all the goodness. Oaky and tart with strawberries underlying everything and coming through strong in the finish. Awesome!

Bottle sampled at Muckfest III. Clear reddish amber pour with a medium beige head. Aroma of strawberries, cream and tangy sourness. Strawberry and cream flavor with some boozy liquor character before a sour finish.

Bottle shared by ogglethorp at Muckfest III...thanks Brian! - Pours murky light brown with a tan ring of head. Nose is butterscoth, light cherry, a bit of sourness, and a touch of plastic. Taste is a little limp, with fizzy Smarties and light strawberry.

Bottle shared at MuckFest 3 - Saturday Edition. Pours a richly haze deeper amber pour, touches of orange and pinkish glow hit the fiery glow in the body. A frothy tannish head stays as a thicker ring, good lacing and sticks around, well carbonated. Aromas are oak, sticky malts, touches of molasses. Toffee, toast, vanilla and oak meet a firm strawberry element. A bit tart, jammy and fresh. A touch tart, seedy. Initial is medium bodied, a bit foamy with some growing carbonation. Bretty funk, touches of tartness, strawberries and sticky malts. Oak, funk, and toffee. Touches of spirit, heat grow into middle and backend. A bit hot, the strawberries certainly come through well. Heat, spirit, touches of dry funk, oaky tannins into finish. Not bad, but hot.

On tap at Monks Cafe for Allagash Day last year. Pours a deep, deceptively dark amber mahogany with a thick, fluffy, one-finger white head. Tightly bubbled and leaves tons of lacing. Aroma of freshly picked strawberries, raspberry jam, freshly baked bread, farmhouse funk, and slightly odd hints of earth and glue. The aroma is outstanding in its complexity and uniqueness, as well as its flawless masking of any traces of alcohol. Full, tight body with a heaviness that balances out the sweet tartness of the brew. Mouthfeel is bittersweet, fruity, and ultimately incredibley smooth and mellow. Finishes with a bit of strawberry tart and huge oaky flavors. This is a truly special, exceptionally unique, sour ale.
375 thanks to AirForceHops. Orange/brown color. Big pop of the cork but decent carbonation overall. Strawberry, chocolate and sour come together in a pleasant way. Glad to have tried this.

On tap at pizza port Carlsbad. Dark reddish brown with a creamy off white head. Caramel strawberry and green apple aroma and taste with a lot of red wine character and solid notes of vanilla and oak velvety palate and a tart finish of more green apple and caramel. Excellent.

375ml shared by duchessedubourg.

Appearance : Hazy amber with a small head.

Aroma : Stawberries with rubbery notes. Notes of strawberry jam.

Taste : Nice strawberries with spices. Light alcohol on finish with more strawberries.

Overall : Nice strawberries presence. The light rubbery feeling on the nose bugged me a bit. Enjoyable fruity profile but could be better integrated. Overall nice beer but nothing so special. Vrienden was way better.

Bottle thanks to ChuckyCheese (BA). Poured into two cantillon tulips, one had a nice little finger of foam that lasted until the very last sip and the others head faded very quickly, brown pour with a distinct reddish tint. Aroma: At first I get a lot earthy, damp forest floor like aromas but the strawberries are very present and strong. Some molasses is still perceptible in the aroma. Taste is sweet and tart, the strawberry and oak flavors are dominant here. Palate: Medium-light carbonation, a bit of alcohol perceptible on the finish. Very nice beer, it grew on to me.

4oz pour at the Lupulin Reunuless at RFD DC.  Pours a hazy, copper amber with a creamy white head.  Big nose, malty, boozy, tropical fruits.  Flavor is fruity, some booze, tropical fruits, vanilla, wood, some berry patch.  Medium bodied, tart, sweet, fruity finish.  Perhaps a few too many flavors competing.

Bottle courtesy of dcschiller.  Pour is murky caramel with an off-white head.  Smells like a belgian hospital with touches of strawberry! And thats not a bad thing.  Huge aromas of bandaid, aspirin, strawberry, light florals, oak, and funk.  Flavor shows pretty much the same with some additional earthiness as well as some brown sugar.  Overall it is extremely well balanced and complex enough to be interesting. More please.

375ml bottle with several months on it.  The pour yields a rather hazy, deep garnet colored body with a glowing amber edge that shows when backlit.  A frothy head is initially tall and rocky, slowly collapsing to a smoothed out, dense, lasting blanket with ramped up edges.  Random skinny flares and jagged paint-splatter splotches of lace mark the glass.The nose is initially a bit funky, hinting at some plastic band-aid.  After walking away from the glass for a good twenty minutes or so, however, it mostly blows off to reveal a sweet-tart, rustic, slightly earthy dark Belgian aroma.  The brown candy sugar base sports a darkly caramelized edge, working with burnt molasses and peanutty barrel wood to lend some toastiness.  Strawberries are distinct, yet mostly subdued, giving an air of red berry tartness that works nicely with dusty brett that has also crept in.  In short, if you can wait for the plastic note to dissipate, it smells pretty damn nice, but you shouldnt have to do that.Flavors are a bit different.  The brett really asserts itself, suggesting of dusty funk and even some grilled green apple, while the strawberries concentrate quite a bit more than the nose would suggest.  Caramel, blackened candy sugar, and burnt molasses are all fairly well attenuated, having been eaten up by the brett.  Sharp, twangy, sour mash bourbon shows true character of the buggy, old wood.  I thought it might get clean away from the plastic elements, but then I burped and got a mouth full of band-aid....yuck.For a brew of this magnitude, the palate comes across rather dry, sporting a lively, peppery carbonation up front, moving towards a dry, slightly oxidized finish that I actually like a great deal.  There is very little in the way of cloying sugar.Overall, Id say this beer was a great idea that unfortunately suffers a bit from quality control (or lack thereof).  The band-aid notes, while not as overt as many other infected beers that Ive had, are unforgivable nonetheless.  Its too bad, because wed be talking elite 4.0+ status if it were cleaner.
375 bottle.  Was really surprised how well the strawberries came through.  Very well done.  Aroma has strawberries. Tastes is smooth and sweet.  Very well made.

375 ML bottle, AirFroreHops Shared this bottle with me.  Cloudy brown pour, fluffy white head. A bit of floating sediment in the glass. Aroma is oak and tart strawberry and some sugar.  Flavor is very close to what youd expect with the aroma, very subtle oak wood at first with a little tart  finish. A hint of molasses up front giving way to slightly sour and acidic cherry on the finish. The label states this is 10.8% ABV. I dont pick out the  ABV at all, it is hidden nicely. 
This is a border line sour ale/ Wild Ale in my eyes.  If you like slightly sour brews, you will like this!

375 ML bottle, I purchased at the Brewery on the limited release day. Cloudy brown pour, fluffy white head. A bit of floating sediment in the glass. Aroma is oak and tart strawberry and some sugar.  Flavor is very close to what youd expect with the aroma, very subtle oak wood at first with a little sour finish. A hint of molasses up front giving way to slightly sour and acidic cherry on the finish. The label states this is 10.8% ABV. I dont pick out the  ABV at all, it is hidden nicely. 
This is a border line sour ale/ Wild Ale in my eyes.  If you like slightly sour brews, you will like this!!

(375ml bottle courtesy of chuckycheese and shared at Daks final four tasting!!).  Pours a cloud apricot color with off-white head.  Aroma has strawberry and funky notes.  Taste is sour with tart strawberries.  Medium bodied with a smooth finish.  This was really awesome!
Dschiller share.pours a nice  Straw color with a white head. Sour strawberry asprin funk. Great.
Cloudy brown pour, light head.  Aroma of strawberry jam, balsamic, yeast, orange peel.  Flavor is strawberry, balsamic, oak, tart cherries, good stuff!

Bottle thanks to Mike, poured into a perfect pint glass... This pours a light watery reddish orange. The head is off white, watery and whispy, but has decent retention and lacing. Weird color but ok... The aroma is shockingly decent for a strawberry beer. Strawberries are dominant on the front and they come off nice and fresh. I also get some oak and lactic sour. Cant tell this is a quad, no notes of that at all... The taste is a total 180, the strawberries are now stale and old, gross finish. I try to get past the berries, pull out some oak, and hint of dark fruits, not sour enough at all. 

From the description and being an Allagash beer I was expecting total garbage. It wasnt quite that bad but not a recommend. So essentially it exceeded my expectations but not good.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2016 Sampled thanks to someone at the post NotB tasting! Poured a cloudy amber orange with a yellowish tan head that lasted throughout the beer. Aroma had a note of tart strawberries a bit of funk and a sweet grain backing. Flavor had a light tartness from the strawberries with some funk backing and a bit of oak. Comes together nicely.

Appearance:  Pours a dark murky iced tea with a thin white cap.

Aroma: Ripe strawberry, funk and brown sugar.

Taste: Strawberry, earth, brett, tart grape skin. Theres some wood, but its very subtle.

Mouthfeel: Juicy, lively carbonation.

Overall:  A really well made treat of a beer. A balanced fruity funky beer.

On tap at churchills anniversary poured a mellow reddish amber. Smells of Brett, sour funk, red fruits, and bread. Tastes a nice sour up front with some tart red fruits and finishes with a slight wheat flavor. Pretty good sour but over hyped in my eyes.

A dark hazed amber ale with a super thick moka head. In aroma, smooth lactic and creamy, muskey notes, light cherries. In mouth, a lighter musty malt, molds, a bit earthy, light sour cherries, but not very sour and acidic  as expected. On tap at Brewvival, Feb. 26 2011.

2 oz pour from the keg at Brewvival on 2/26/11.  dark orange pour with a slim off white head.  great sour funky nose with brett, pedio and thin layers of strawberries.  medium body with a high level of sourness and a sharp tartness from the fruit.  sour finish with more light levels of strawberries.

Bottle Pour.  Pours a murky reddish brown color with a wispy white head.  Aroma is of brett, funky strawberries, and a little yogurt.  Flavor is very close to what youd expect with the aroma, sweet at first with a little sour finish.  A hint of molasses up front giving way to slightly sour and acidic strawberry on the finish.  Clean and smooth mouthfeel.  Nice!

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2011 On tap at Pizza Ports Barrel Blast. Pours with a hazed amber body with a lasting off-white head. Aromas of oak, tannic, barnyard, fruity, with light strawberry (at least on the nose). Flavors have a much stronger berry flavor, light acidity, funk, tannic, oak and vanilla. Lively bubbles with a dry finish. 3.8 Also in a bottle thanks to LtDan. Pours with a hazed brown body with a tan head. Aromas of strawberries, other berries, funk, manure, caramel, horseblanket and straw. Flavors are acidic, big, peppery, straw, berries, vanilla. Fruity. Fresh. Medium to lively bubbles, tastes big. Good! 3.9

On tap at Monks Cafe for Allagash Day. Pours a deep, deceptively dark amber mahogany with a thick, fluffy, one-finger white head. Tightly bubbled and leaves tons of lacing. Aroma of freshly picked strawberries, raspberry jam, freshly baked bread, farmhouse funk, and slightly odd hints of earth and glue. The aroma is outstanding in its complexity and uniqueness, as well as its flawless masking of any traces of alcohol. Full, tight body with a heaviness that balances out the sweet tartness of the brew. Mouthfeel is bittersweet, fruity, and ultimately incredibley smooth and mellow. Finishes with a bit of strawberry tart and huge oaky flavors. This is a truly special, exceptionally unique, sour ale. Definitely a must try for Jolly Pumpkin fans!

On draft at Monks Cafe.

Pours a dark golden ruby color with dark golden orange hues when held to a light source. Two finger creamy, pillowy off white head with excellen retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that coats the glas with soapy lacing.

Slightly funky aroma with lots of vinous character, earthy oak and dark fruit. Smells slightly vinegary with vinous dark fruit, especially tart cherries, grape, strawberry and plum. The barrel aging adds a nice earthy oak and vanilla. Slight bug presence but this is all about the barrel and vinous dark fruit.

Slightly tart and puckering but not too harsh or acidic. Dry with again a lot of vinous dark fruit, funky bugs and earthy oak. Slight lactic creaminess adds depth and complexity and there is a really nice balance of sweet fruit, puckering vinegar sourness, oak and vanilla. Each sip picks up more flavor. Plenty of sweet fruit notes, especially cherry, strawberry and grape. Lots of dry Brett and a mouthwatering tart finish that leaves me salivating for more. Recommended.

Co-rate!  Tap at ﻿Pizza Port Carlsbad. Hazy reddish amber color. Aroma of concord grapes and strawberries. Taste is similar, with a bit of cream and tangerine.  Beautiful beer, and possibly my favorite of the event.  Very unique.
Tap at ﻿Pizza Port Carlsbad.  Hazy reddish amber color.  Aroma of concord grapes and strawberries.  taste is similar, with a bit of tangerine.  Nice.

Strawberry pour with sudsy pink head. Woody Brett on the nose coupled with strawberries, hops, oak, and a distinct barnyard quality. The alcohol is masked very well especially for this being 10% abv. Very dry, bitter, sour finish without much of an alcohol burn.

Beautiful pink opaqueness lay in the glass covered in super big, super dense pink-touched suds.  Nose is fucking brilliant...sour brett and strawberries laced with lovely cheesy funk.  My dear lord.  Thick yeasty body loaded with some old-school fantome-like phenols and vivid notes of the strawberries.  Aftertaste is practically all strawberry, in an fresh and organic way.  Damn this is fucking delicious.

(Draught)  Pours a cloudy orange-brown body with a medium beige head.  Aroma of florals, some yogurt, strawberries, vanilla, and oak.  Flavor of florals, brett, light lacto, rosehips, strawberries, and vanilla with a warming finish.
Draft @ Barcade. Ruby brown pour with some light head. Huge oak, yeast and slight fruit aroma. Flavor is wood heavy but ends with strawberry, tart and slight funk flavor throughout.
Draft.  Pours an amber crimson body with an off white head and modest lacing.  Belgian fruit tones, strawberry jam, light spices, and maple.  Dry with some nice funk and leather.  A fan.

Pouring at session one of Belgian Beer Fest in Boston.  Pours a ruddy hazed brown with a thin beige head.  Jam, slightly plastic and phenolic, funk.  Strawberries right away, tangy and tart.  Lots of berries and jamminess.  Sweet and malty leading into a slow funky tangy finish.

BBF 10
Murky Orange Brown pour with no head.  aroma is vinous wood, strawberry, funky yeastiness.  Flavor is deep woodiness, tart strawberries, some yogurty funk, light acetic qualities.  Nice complexity of flavor, not super sour, but really enjoyable

Tap at Barcade, Brooklyn. Pours amber-brown with a modest, white head. Fruity aroma with some wood and tartness. Flavor is sour and fruity, but not overly sour, with some mild funk notes. Body is medium to full with light carbonation and a fairly vinous quality. Finishes mostly with linger sour notes, but there is light fruit sweetness and some oak. Excellent.

tap at Barcade Allagash event - hazy red pour. really fruity, strawberry, raspberries, fruity, light caramel sweetness, earthy and funk. well balanced with tart smooth body. finishes a bit oaky, vanilla at the end. vineous with only a hint of booze.. an amazing feat for 10%abv.

Tap at Barcade. Poured a reddish brown with a thin white head. The nose is sweet,woody,oaken, and fruity. What struck me first was the oaked sour notes. The Four is a really good base beer, and the oaking and aging enhances it nicely. The range of flavors runs very deep in this beer. From fruity to slightly sour, from candied sugars to oak barrels. Its complex, yet earthy. A very interesting and good beer.

Tasted on draft at Lush CBC event.  Pours cloudy brown with a thin bubbly head.  Nose of malt, stewed red fruits, prune, and raisin.  Flavors are bitter chocolate, sour, stewed red fruit, and a nice maltiness.  The carbonation is low, the body is full, and the finish is long with bitter, sour, and fruity flavors.  This beer is very complex.

Allagash avange in tap at smallbar division... Pours a combination of  
amber red/caramel brown with a thin frothy just off-white head...  
Strawberry essence immediately comes into play with some nice oaky  
undertones... Flavors are tart strawberry which remain quite present  
throughout which give way to some sweetness and finishes off on a  
slightly bitter note with some added vanilla oak tannins. Pretty tame  
from an abv perspective without much heat although it does catch up  
with time. Some acidity upfront that quickly mellows out.  Medium  
bodied overall with ur average amount of carbonation. Not too bad.
8/4/7/4/15
On tap at the PP Belgian Ale Fest 10.  Pours a cloud red/ brown.  Sweet dark malts, lots of oak, strawberries, bourbon notes, and plum.  Interesting beer, I thought it was pretty good.

Tap at Blind Tiger.  Deep brown beer with no head at all and light pinkish highlights.  Aroma is lightly berryish over a heavy oaky woodiness.  Even more wood here than in the bourbon-aged four.  Malts are quite subtle and dried out.  A bit of plum and brown sugar, but the oak really clobbers this one to death.  I think it was a good idea, but I dont think it was terribly well executed.

Tap at Blind Tiger.  For whatever reason, I got head on my beer, while it was dead for pretty much everyone else.  Poured dark red-brown.  Aroma was slightly tart with quite a bit of oak character coming out.  Taste was pretty similar, very oaky but now overpowering, along with tangy strawberries and malt background.  Average palate with a slightly boozy finish.

Draft at the Blind Tiger.  Brown pour with a slightly red hint, no head.  Bourbon in the aroma, woody, with some dark fruit, sugar and hints of strawberries.  The flavor is slightly sour / bitter from the oak but the fruityness of the strawberries and malt balance this well.  Bourbon lingers in the finish.  Good palate.

Tap at Blind Tiger. Great great stuff. No head. Light strawberries, big oak, buttery and vanilla aroma. Tons of oak and a sweet, juicy finish. A small punch of tartness and a little funkiness makes this really interesting. Reminds me in a way of CL SFTO Wine Barrel. Delicious!

Surprising beer, if I were to imagine the Four going into a barrel and strawberries added I would not think this would emerge. It has become a funky beer heading into Oude Bruin territory.  The beer pours still with a reddish dark brown color.  Aroma is sour-ish strawberry and it has the whole acidic thing working for it. Taste is like a muddled Oude Bruin.    Starts light sour and goes oak-y thats comes off as a bit leafy and grassy.  Has a long lightly acidic aftertaste.  My one issue is the beer is well under-carbonated, which makes it come off as watery and too light.  But otherwise a very nice experience and I hope the Allagash guys keep doing the sour thing, theyre good at it.Tap at Blind Tiger, tulip glass.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Tap at Blind Tiger: Deep amber pour, with a fading head. The aroma has a lot of oak character. Somewhat boozy and woody, with bourbon suggestions, but no strawberries. The flavor has lots of woody and oakey flavors, with underlying dark berry notes. Later on the palate theres some toasted toffee followed by more smooth oak suggestions. A nice experiment, with an ideal amount of oak character.

Sample @ EBF 2/2007.  Pours a cloudy reddish-orange with an off-white head.  Aroma is strawberry and oak with some slight notes of spice and acid as well.  Taste is tart but smooth, with detectable strawberry, oak, vanilla, and other subtle characteristics.  I absolutely loved this beer and hope they begin to sell it commercially; it takes their excellent Four to another level.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2009 Tap at Boston EBF 2007.  Cloudy copper body topped by a small beige head.  Unless you piss in the barrels you really cant make a bad beer if you base it on the excellent Allagash Four.  Although this is the Allagash Four aged with strawberries I didnt get much, if any, strawberry flavours.  What I got was my faithful Allagash Four with an added unfocussed fruity tartness and a carbonation that seemed a bit too lively.  The drinkability was increased but it wasnt as round or deep as the original.  Still very good but something tells me that it was put together without putting much thought into it.  I mean, they even misspelled Avancée

EBF 07.  Pours a muddled dull dark copper with a slight lasting head.  Aroma is slightly sour with some lacto, frutiy sweetness, but kept in check with some tart quality and some oak and vanilla.  Nice full flavor with hints of strawberry, oak, vanilla, earthy phenols, spicy yeast, and a great crisp slightly tart finish.  Light sour qualities from the acids in the fruit make this much better than the original Four.  Completely different beer.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2014 2007 draught at EBF Feb 10thDark, moderately hazy brown body has tan edges and a small dull-tan head that fades rather quickly to partial cover, leaving light lacing behind.Soft, sumptuous malts lick the nose, delivering chocolate, sweet raisins, easygoing vanilla creaminess and only a slight streak of fruitiness that can not be noted as strawberry (which most certainly fully fermented).  Oak gives a touch of zestiness, but the vinousness is very controlled, leaving a clean, smooth, Belgian yeastiness on the end.  Toffee and more chocolate-covered raisins continue to ease the nose as a hint of acids are notable on the finish, after warming.  Refreshingly dry, but extremely reserved (fitting well with the nature of the beer), it only seems to take the light prune/currant vinousness and run with it, adding just a hint of sourishness that is wrapped about dry caramel.  Medium to medium-high strength of aroma, but not forceful in any way.  Really a shame they arent going to release this.  You could really sit down with a bottle and expand your mind!  Alcohol not noted, other than some minor drying notes that are folded nicely in with the vinousness and light acidic dryness.Aroma dosent prepare for the flavor, nor does having had Four or Bourbon Four.  This is nothing like it.  Not too much like a quadruppel, but maybe sweet enough to put you in the ballpark of something like westy 12.  The yeast isnt quite as refined and isolated in the flavor, as that one, of course, and the barrel adds light molasses/caramel/vanilla notes.  But what really struck me the most is the absolute velvety softness of the texture/malt.  Medium-sweet chocolate, with light dark fruit/berry notes and soft, comforting oakiness.  Carbonation is low, allowing it to really stick to the palate, but a very light yeast tartness on the finish helps give it some balance.  All sorts of chocolates, caramels and toffees can be discerned with warming/breathing.  Sweeter than I remember four being, with less apparent alcohol and sharp esters.  Probably more a Belgian Dark Strong, but the lines blur.  8/4/8/4/172014 draught at Publick House, March 14th.Ha, had the last one over 7 years ago...wow.My review seems pretty close to my feelings on the new one.  Having not remembered what this beer was about while having it the second time, I was ready to write-off the sweetness as too much both from malt and fruit sugar, but realizing that this, after all, a Quad, it seems a little more apt.  Granted, I still think the beer is a bit too heavy on the sweet and sour aspect (with too much acetic/citric acid) but you cant just look at this as a straight Sour golden with strawberries.  Anyways, certainly still enjoyable and seems like it would be even better in 6 months to a year after some of the intensity mellows and things congeal.  8/4/8/3/15.Score is an average of both years.

EBF 2007: Hazy brown with a loose tan head. Aroma, vanilla and caramel, some oak. Flavor, sweet and oaky, some caramel, yeast, a hint of strawberries, and bit of sourness. This did well, I wasnt a very big fan of the Four, but this was almost a completely new beer.
ebf 07. this beer was banging. not overly sweet or thick like a lot of quads. the oak and strawberries hooked this the fuck up. it was mellow(for a quad) but sour with a trace of strawberry.

EBF 2007 - this is one of the first beers I tried at this event - unlike some of the other barrel-aged beers these guys brought, this one was not that overpoweringly woody - the regular Four is rather sweet, but the time spent in the barrels mellowed that out quite a bit - there is a gentle tart, almost sour quality to the beer, which most certainly comes from the strawberries (which are quite present, but far in the background), but one might almost mistake it for a little brett character (since it gives the beer a slight flemish sour character) - quite dry, with the wood coming in late - Four is a rather aggressive ale, but after aging on the fruit, it has become quite delicate, with slight white wine flavor (probably also from the fruit) - quite nice.
